thread.title: Tegel fronts trade buyers; UXC close to deal with Computer Sciences Corporation
thread.title_full: Tegel fronts trade buyers; UXC close to deal with Computer Sciences Corporation | afr.com

author: afr.com
title: Tegel fronts trade buyers; UXC close to deal with Computer Sciences Corporation
text:
It would not surprise to see the IPO of New Zealand poultry producer Tegel Foods pushed into 2016 given the state of equity markets, sources told Street Talk. Chris Hillock by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Tegel Foods management has met with potential trade buyers believed to include Thailand's Charoen Pokphand Group and global meat processing giant JBS, as owner Affinity Equity Partners nears a decision about whether to seek a trade sale or initial public offering for the poultry business.
It's understood Tegel management gave a high level presentation to interested trade groups at a meeting in Sydney recently, which was described as similar in nature to metings held with listed equities investors.
Sources said Affinity was hopeful of finding a buyer before the end of the calendar year but stressed there was no formal sale process underway.
Without an auction - and with only two months until much of the market shuts down for the annual holiday season - Affinity would have to move quickly.
Of course, the trade talks come as Affinity and advisers Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank keep a close eye on listed equities markets, and investor demand for IPOs.
It's understood Goldman and Deutsche's research analysts have been briefed and are preparing pre-marketing research reports, which are due in the market towards the end of October.
It would not surprise, however, to see the IPO pushed into 2016 given the state of equity markets, sources said. Potential listings for the likes of radiology group I-MED and New Zealand's Carters have already been deferred until the new year and they are unlikely to be the last.
Elsewhere, sources told Street Talk an announcement from ANZ Banking Group on the sale of its Esanda Dealer Finance unit could be made as early as Tuesday.
 Macquarie is the frontrunner [and has been named preferred bidder] to grab the $8.3 billion loan portfolio, estimated to have a $1.1 billion book value, although China's HNA Group was still in the race over the weekend. As Street Talk revealed on Sunday , the third bidding group, involving ASX-listed Pepper Group and New-York-based York Capital Management, was told by vendor ANZ and its adviser Deutsche Bank that they would no longer be proceeding with their bid.
Morgan Stanley analysts are tipping that Macquarie would require $623 million to $1.1 billion capital should it buy the unit. The analysts based their call on a $1 billion to $1.5 billion purchase price, which would represent 0.9-times to 1.4-times book value.
Macquarie last raised equity to fund an aircraft portfolio acquisition in March, tapping institutional investors for $500 million by way of a placement. That deal was done at $73.50 a share. Macquarie stock last traded at $77.16.
Finally, IT services company UXC Limited is understood to be close to announcing an agreed deal with acquirer US multinational Computer Sciences Corporation.
The parties have been in talks for several months.A period of exclusivity is expected at a price of $1.26 per share plus an interim dividend.
Nomura is said to have fielded interest on behalf of UXC.
UXC shares have rallied strongly - up from about 80Â¢ in April - and investors will have to overcome the fact, that despite negotiations starting some months ago, the stock is trading above the offer price.
The shares closed at $1.33 on Monday.
Reverse break fees are thought to be in place. Geoff Lord who founded UXC is deputy chairman.
